As someone who taught economics, financial literacy, and media literacy (and has three books on how to teach it), I wholeheartedly agree it should be taught more. There, are, however, two snags that hold up such programs: How do we define Financial Literacy? There is no set curriculum, and I have seen everything from separate courses to a single unit in a math class count. Some teachers focus on big picture topics like mortgages and long-term savings/investment, others on more immediate and “real” issues for students like buying a car (or food) or how to pay for college. I personally include lots of behavioral economics (what nudges our financial decisions), but of course that’s my thing.What do we take out? As an economics teacher, I see everything as a trade-off, especially with regard to optimizing the limited resource of time in a school day. To teach any new topic comprehensively, something has to come out, and everything already taught has their defenders (the STEM turf-protectors have had the upper hand, though they are yielding a bit to the STEAM advocates of late). Then there are also all the other great ideas that need to be introduced (sex ed/health, civics, ethics, computers, data science, speech). All of these are competing to grab a little space in a student’s day, and by introducing them all, education becomes a series of hors d’oeurvres rather than a meal of any substance.I’m not saying FL should not and cannot be taught, but it is a daunting task to redo any curriculum. Be well.
